comment: I still love how much of that movie was hand drawn
IIRC, it was used during the bike sequences.
It was mentioned in the special features, haven't watched it in a few years.
Also one of the first to use computers to help record and mix music.
The one source I'm finding is saying that all backgrounds / light sources were hand-painted
Riiiiiiiiiight, that's why I remember Akira as being special
The whole film was done in 24 fps.  Every frame was animated.  And apparently some frames had as many as 8 or 9 layers
Watching the special features, and yeah, they did use computer animations.

"Computer-generated imagery was also used in the film, primarily to animate the pattern indicator used by Doctor ≈ånish, but it was additionally used to plot the paths of falling objects, model parallax effects on backgrounds, and tweak lighting and lens

Nope, another explanation behind wage stagnation, and also another argument for how destructive shareholders will be to capitalism in the long run if we don't put a leash on them
Any chance the bastards at the top will actually THINK about the long term now?
Or are we doomed to short term gain and long term pain?
Pre-1980's, companies typically invested less than 50% of their profit back into shareholders
The remainder was put back into the workers and long-term investments
At some point, the directive changed, and now the standard is that 93% of profits go towards the shareholders.  This is now the norm and what is expected.
New Patreon Post: Catch of the Day https://www.patreon.com/posts/catch-of-day-37040820
Combine that with the legal obligation corporations have to make money for the shareholders, and it makes a lot of sense.
She was catching fish, but then she caught herself a man :ptv-snicker:
So really, the problem is that too much money is being siphoned towards the top.
